q: How do you get actinomycosis?
a: The bacteria that cause actinomycosis normally live harmlessly in the body. They only cause an infection if they get into the lining of areas such as the mouth or gut. You cannot spread the infection to other people.

q: What are the symptoms of actinomycosis?
a: Symptoms of actinomycosis depend on what part of the body is affected. For example, in the jaw or mouth, symptoms may include lumps in your cheek or neck, difficulty chewing, and pus leaking from your skin. In the lungs, symptoms may include shortness of breath, chest pain, a cough, and pus leaking from the skin on your chest.

q: When should I see a doctor if I have symptoms of actinomycosis?
a: You should see a GP if you have symptoms of actinomycosis.

q: How is actinomycosis treated?
a: Actinomycosis is treated with antibiotics. Treatment starts off in the hospital with antibiotics given directly into a vein. When you're well enough to go home, you'll be given antibiotic tablets to take for a few months. Surgery may also be needed to drain areas of pus (abscesses) and remove infected skin.

q: How can actinomycosis be prevented?
a: Actinomycosis is very rare, but you can help reduce your risk by looking after your teeth and gums.

q: What are the possible causes of actinomycosis?
a: Possible causes of actinomycosis include tooth decay and mouth infections, mouth injuries, inhaling food or liquid, intrauterine devices (IUDs), dental or tummy surgery, and radiotherapy. People with type 2 diabetes or a weakened immune system are more likely to get actinomycosis.

q: Can actinomycosis affect any part of the body?
a: Yes, any part of the body can be infected with actinomycosis, but the head and neck, chest, tummy, and pelvis are most commonly affected.

q: What are the symptoms of actinomycosis in the tummy?
a: Symptoms of actinomycosis in the tummy include diarrhea or constipation, pain, a lump or swelling in your tummy, and pus leaking from the skin.

q: What are the symptoms of actinomycosis in the pelvis?
a: Symptoms of actinomycosis in the pelvis include pain low down in your tummy, vaginal bleeding or unusual discharge, and a lump or swelling in your lower tummy.

q: How long do I need to take antibiotics for actinomycosis?
a: It's important to keep taking antibiotics until they're finished, even when you feel better. The duration of antibiotic treatment for actinomycosis is usually a few months.
